title: 107_hr1865
content: Radiation exposure compensation technical amendments. The Radiation Exposure Compensation Act is amended to include specific changes related to geographic areas, types of cancers covered, and eligibility criteria for compensation. The Radiation Exposure Compensation Act is amended to remove references to lung cancer, specify conditions for uranium mine workers, and set a deadline for amendments implementation. The Radiation Exposure Compensation Act Amendments of 2000 require the Attorney General to issue revised regulations for the Act. Section 6 now allows individuals to provide substantiation through affidavits when filing a claim. The Radiation Exposure Compensation Act Amendments of 2000 now allow individuals to submit affidavits for employment history or residence verification. No individual can receive more than one payment under this Act. The Radiation Exposure Compensation Act Amendments of 2000 require the General Accounting Office to submit reports to Congress every 18 months on the administration of the Act by the Department of Justice. The reports must analyze claims, awards, administrative costs, and the Department of Justice budget related to the Act. Additionally, certain sections of the Act were amended to provide compensation for eligible claimants. Section 3630 of the Energy Employees Occupational Illness Compensation Program Act of 2000 is amended to provide separate treatment for certain claimants under the Radiation Exposure Compensation Act. An individual eligible for compensation under the Radiation Exposure Compensation Act will receive $50,000 and medical benefits for their illness. The compensation and benefits provided are separate from those under the Act, and payments are made from the compensation fund established under the Act. The Radiation Exposure Compensation Act provides $50,000 and medical benefits to eligible individuals. Survivors of covered individuals who die before the effective date specified may also receive compensation. The President will establish procedures to notify individuals or their survivors of the available benefits. The Energy Employees Occupational Illness Compensation Program Act of 2000 provides compensation and benefits effective July 31, 2001. Amendments are made to the table of sections, including the removal of section 3630. Amendments are made to the Radiation Exposure Compensation Act, including changes to section 3630 and section 3(e) regarding compensation for radiation exposure.
